title: Rice: Trump’s handling of impeachment ‘extremely detrimental’ to national security
text:
Which is among the reasons why Rice, the former national security adviser and UN ambassador under President Barack Obama, is so concerned about how she sees the Trump administration responding to the threat of impeachment — and what that may portend for America’s national security.

“Because the Clinton White House was so deliberate about keeping the impeachment effort, counter-impeachment effort, in a very tight and isolated circle, and preserving our ability to continue to govern on everything else, it didn’t get into our national security bloodstream the way it is today,” Rice said in an interview for POLITICO’s Women Rule podcast. “And it is today, because: one, it’s a national security issue that’s led to the inquiry, but also because the president seems to be taking this all on himself, and all of the public communication from him these days is about impeachment or some threat related to impeachment.”

“It’s going to be very different and very difficult to wall off the work of governing, whether domestically or internationally,” said Rice. “And I think that’s going to be extremely detrimental to our interests, which … I think have already been grossly compromised over the last three years.”

In her new memoir, Tough Love: My Story of the Things Worth Fighting For, Rice recounts some of the signature events she had to deal with in 1998, the year Clinton was impeached by the House of Representatives: the breakout of war in the Horn of Africa, Congo plunged into the “African World War,” and al-Qaeda’s attacks on the U.S. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. “It was brutal,” said Rice.

She credits her ability to appropriately respond to those events to, in part, the way the Clinton White House walled off its impeachment response from the rest of the administration.

Another difference between then and now, says Rice, is America’s standing in the world, which she says has “plummeted” during the Trump administration.

“We are denigrating our allies; we’re starting trade wars and other conflicts with our allies; we’re embracing our opponents like Putin, like Kim Jong Un, and heralding them as great leaders and friends when they are anything but,” said Rice. “Right now, up is down and down is up.”

She says that impeachment will only underline some of the concerns that America’s allies have about Trump. “Countries around the world have long started to question our interests, our purpose, and I think in particular they question the president’s interests. Is he acting in our national interest? I would say the evidence is no.”

Rice’s book follows her journey from Washington, DC, where she was raised as one of the few African-American students in Washington’s most elite and expensive schools, to her time as a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford. After earning her Ph.D., she joined the Clinton administration and worked at the State Department as a 30-something “with a baby on my hip.” A Brookings scholar during the Bush years, she joined President Barack Obama’s administration at the outset, first as UN Ambassador, then as national security adviser.

It was during those years with Obama that Rice attended the 2015 White House Correspondents’ Dinner, where she first met the man who would succeed Obama in the Oval Office.

During a break in the evening’s program, as other guests milled about, Rice says she remained seated at her table. “From behind me comes this hulking man, and [he] literally kind of lifts me up out of the chair. And I turn around and I recognized him — obviously, it’s Donald Trump — and he grabs me and hugs me.”

“I want to hasten to say, it wasn’t a gross hug. But it was kind of creepy and strange because I didn’t know him,” said Rice. “But while he was hugging me, he whispered this into my ear: ‘I want you to know you were treated very unfairly over Benghazi,’ a phrase we’ve heard him say — ‘very unfairly.’ He says it a lot; usually about himself, but in this case, it was about me, and that I was doing a good job for the country. And I thanked him, and it was a very pleasant exchange.”

A month later, in June 2015, Trump announced his presidential candidacy, “and all of a sudden everybody and anybody who works for President Obama — and President Obama himself — were the devil incarnate,” said Rice.

Rice says that during the 2016 presidential campaign, she considered publicly divulging Trump’s comment to her. “I just didn’t want to get in the middle of the politics of the campaign, so I kept it to myself,” Rice said. “I actually admit to regretting that some days now.”

To hear more from Ambassador Susan Rice, listen to the full podcast here. Women Rule takes listeners backstage with female bosses for real talk on how they made it and what advice they have for women looking to lead.
